title: How can TOTALLY PURE water kill someone? - Quora

response.answer_text: To be more specific, if you drink lots of water, your blood (and other extracellular fluids) become more dilute, which is to say that they contain more water and less of the other stuff like salts, sugars, etc., that they normally carry. The membranes of your cells are permeable to water, and since the concentration of salts, sugars, etc., in the cells is now higher that in the liquid outside, we get osmosis of water into the cells, which makes them swell up. Mostly, this isn’t a big deal. It doesn’t do much harm if your liver cells or muscle cells or kidney cells swell up a little bit. But, there’s one rather important organ that is inside a rigid bone box. When your brain cells swell, your brain has nowhere to expand. It just squeezes tighter and tighter against the skull, and it’s kind of like having a concussion over the whole brain. This can do a lot of damage, and among other things cause you to stop breathing. Disclaimer: I didn’t watch the video, but I talk about a case of lethal water intoxication in my biochemistry class.

The Youtube video you referenced is a nice compilation of relative toxicities; I’ve bookmarked it for use elsewhere. Thanks! Regarding “water poisoning” AKA “water intoxication” . . . and sometimes “hyponatremia” (though that’s not quite the same thing”, the articles here:Water intoxication - Wikipediaand here:https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC1770067/provide detailed information. But basically, MANY body processes depend on the correct ratios of water to sodium and potassium ions (among others). When you drink too much water, you screw up the ratios, which screws up the body processes . . . which causes you to die!  By the way, the video referenced with the original question is worth watching for anyone who does not have a clear understanding of relative toxicities.
